description: Known in English since 1601, but rare before c.1850. From Latin hybrida, a variant of hibrida (“a mongrel; specifically, offspring of a tame sow and a wild boar”).

adjectives.description: hybrid (comparative more hybrid, superlative most hybrid)

examples: a hybrid mix of jazz and punk

entries.meaning: (of a car) Running on both fuel (gasoline/diesel) and electricity (battery or energy from the sun).
(biology) Offspring resulting from cross-breeding different entities, e.g. two different species or two purebred parent strains.

definitionGroups.group: Something of mixed origin or composition; often, a tool or technology that combines the benefits of formerly separate tools or technologies.

entries.meaning: (linguistics) A word whose elements are derived from different languages.
A hybrid vehicle (especially a car), one that runs on both fuel (gasoline/diesel) and electricity (battery or energy from the sun).
examples: All our family drive hybrids because they're greener.

entries.meaning: (cycling) A bicycle that is a compromise between a road bike and a mountain bike.
(golf) A golf club that combines the characteristics of an iron and a wood.
An electronic circuit constructed of individual devices bonded to a substrate or PCB.
A computer that is part analog computer and part digital computer.
